abstract.p: Traditional device fingerprinting methods primarily rely on data-intensive deep learning models, treating devices as black boxes. However, these approaches suffer from high computational complexity and sensitivity to noise, making them impractical for large-scale Internet-of-Things (IoT) deployments that demand real-time processing and energy efficiency. To address these challenges, we propose a physics-based fingerprinting model for optical wireless communication (OWC) systems. Instead of relying solely on statistical features, small yet significant non-linear response variations in LEDs are quantified as lumped parameters in an equivalent circuit model, serving as the foundation for physical fingerprint features. This physics-based fingerprint is not only interpretable but also enables compact feature representation, reducing reliance on extensive training data. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves an average classification accuracy of 90.88% under varying signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. Furthermore, compared to convolutional neural network (CNN) and long short-term memory (LSTM)-based models, our approach achieves higher accuracy with significantly lower computational overhead, making it particularly well-suited for resource-constrained IoT environments. By reducing both dataset dimensionality and training sample requirements, our framework provides an efficient and scalable solution for device authentication in OWC networks.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The sixth-generation (6G) network is poised to support a massive Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem, driving transformative applications such as extended reality (XR), augmented and virtual reality (AR/VR), industrial automation, and pervasive smart technologies1–3. However, the existing RF spectrum struggles to accommodate the escalating capacity demands of these diverse services. Leveraging its unregulated wide spectrum and immunity to electromagnetic interference4–6, optical wireless communication (OWC) has emerged as a compelling solution to address the limitations of RF spectrum resources. Much like RF communication, OWC must address critical security challenges to safeguard transmissions against threats such as eavesdropping, denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, jamming, and node compromise. As reliance on OWC networks for secure data transmission grows, enhancing their security has become an increasingly urgent focus.

Numerous research on enhancing the security of OWC networks has explored various mechanisms to address vulnerabilities, including physical-layer security (PLS) strategies, secure coding frameworks, and authentication protocols. Studies have demonstrated the significance of channel characteristics, such as inter-symbol interference (ISI) caused by multipath reflections, in influencing secrecy performance7,8. Mitigation strategies leveraging advanced transmission policies and cooperative access point designs have proven effective in reducing eavesdropping risks. Additionally, secure coding techniques, particularly those based on polar codes, have emerged as a promising approach to degrade eavesdropper channels, ensuring both reliability and confidentiality of transmitted data9. Authentication and key generation protocols tailored for OWC systems, especially those designed for wide-area IoT connectivity and optical OFDM systems, have further enhanced communication security while maintaining computational efficiency10,11. Moreover, optimization-based solutions, such as power allocation policies in NOMA-aided OWC networks, have been shown to effectively balance user fairness, system efficiency, and secrecy rates12. Collectively, these advancements illustrate a multifaceted approach to strengthening the security of OWC networks, addressing both foundational vulnerabilities and system-level challenges in diverse deployment scenarios.

Beyond cryptographic methods, leveraging unique, non-replicable device characteristics as fingerprints represents an effective strategy for physical-layer device identification and authentication. Inconsistent batches and manufacturing tolerances in wireless communication devices, such as Wi-Fi, ZigBee, and LoRa, introduce unintentional modulations, resulting in distinctive device fingerprints13–18. Similarly, optical fingerprints have garnered significant research interest. For instance, a deep learning-based approach for hardware fingerprinting of fiber-optic Ethernet devices was proposed in19, employing a constellation diagram feature extraction method based on a baseband modulation system with amplitude-only waveforms. This method, validated on an intensity modulation/direct detection system with 24 fiber-optic Ethernet devices, achieved classification accuracies of 99.49% and 96.29% under signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) levels of 30 dB and 10 dB, respectively. A feature separation network (TF-FSN) for fingerprinting visible light transmitters was introduced in20, utilizing a two-stage training strategy to construct a robust classifier. This approach achieved recognition and verification accuracies of 92.65% and 98%, respectively, across varying distances and SNR levels. Despite their effectiveness, these methods heavily rely on large datasets for model training, underscoring the lack of lightweight feature extraction techniques for device fingerprinting in OWC systems, particularly under the growing demand for scalability in large-scale IoT deployments and resource-constrained edge computing scenarios. In our prior work21, the feasibility of using circuit parameters derived from an empirical equivalent LED circuit as fingerprint features was preliminarily validated, achieving a classification accuracy of 97.7%. However, the existing model was limited to insufficient features and validating devices, requiring further exploration and improvement.

Motivated by the use of circuit parameters to represent the unique electrical characteristics of devices, this paper derives an accurate equivalent circuit model for LEDs and proposes a lightweight method for extracting LED-based physical fingerprints for device identification in OWC systems. Different from most deep learning-based identification schemes, the proposed method compresses raw signal features containing redundant information and leverages simple machine learning techniques to achieve high classification accuracy. The main contributions of this work are summarized as follows:
We propose an OWC device identification mechanism based on the unique nonlinear transmission response of LEDs, by capturing the LED intrinsic physical characteristics.
An OWC-based experimental testbed is established to collect the fingerprint dataset from commercial LEDs. The PSO algorithm is employed to extract physics-based fingerprints, which are also visualized as a heatmap pattern.
Comprehensive comparisons with traditional deep learning classifiers are conducted. The results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in extracting intrinsic characteristics while maintaining computational efficiency.The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. Section “Proposed method” provides an in-depth discussion of the device identification mechanism in OWC systems and the development of the physics-based fingerprint model. Section “Data collection and fingerprint extraction” describes the fingerprint extraction algorithm alongside the experimental testbed for dataset collection. Section “Results and discussion” presents a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed fingerprint model, including comparisons with advanced deep learning-based schemes. Finally, Section “Discussion” concludes the paper.

sec.title: Intrinsic feature
Data collection and fingerprint extraction
sec.p:
An experimental dataset was constructed using signals from 15 LEDs (Cree, XPE2-White) to investigate the fingerprint characteristics of LEDs. The experimental setup is shown in Fig. 4. A vector network analyzer (VNA, Rohde & Schwarz, ZNB20) generated frequency-sweep signals with a transmitted electrical power of -5 dBm. These signals, amplified by a power amplifier (Mini-Circuits, ZHL-6A-S+), spanned a frequency range of 100 kHz to 100 MHz, with 400 frequency points sampled. A bias-T (Mini-Circuits, ZX85-12G-S+) drove the LEDs with amplified signals under a fixed DC bias of 200 mA. Due to the limited output power of a single LED, the testing distance was set to 10 cm. The lens and photodetector (PD, Newport 1602A), integrated with a trans-impedance amplifier (TIA) featuring sufficient bandwidth, are employed to enhance signal strength. For each LED, the received power spectrum was measured 50 times, averaged, and recorded into the initial dataset.Fig. 4
(a) Different LED samples. (b) Experimental setup for collecting the PSD dataset of LEDs.

To enhance the robustness of the model under varying environmental conditions, Gaussian white noise was introduced to the dataset, simulating realistic noise scenarios with signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs) between 10 dB and 30 dB. This range was chosen to cover both high-quality and challenging signal conditions, reflecting potential real-world applications of the OWC system in environments with varying electromagnetic interference15,20. Specifically, the training set comprised signals from all 15 LEDs, each processed 1,000 times under a fixed SNR of 30 dB, yielding a total of 15,000 training samples. For testing, 3,000 samples were generated under varying noise conditions, with SNRs randomly distributed between 10 dB and 29.9 dB.

Fig. 5 illustrates the power spectral density (PSD) collected from a common photodetector using 15 different LED transmitters. The unique characteristics within the received signal accurately reflect the nonlinear differences of the LEDs, as the measurement position and receiver setup remain consistent throughout the experiments. The red line in Fig. 5 represents the initially collected PSD, while the blue line shows the PSD with added noise at 30 dB. As observed in Fig. 5, the PSDs from different transmitters appear quite similar, making it challenging to distinguish between them. Additionally, spectrum-based features tend to be highly dimensional. Leveraging the physical characteristics discussed in Section 2, we can efficiently extract physics-based fingerprint features directly from the received signal’s PSD, as demonstrated in (10).Fig. 5
Initial (red line) and noised PSDs (blue line) from 15 LED-based transmitters (from Tx1 to Tx15).

Fig. 6 illustrates the heatmap patterns of the extracted physics-based fingerprints for 15 different LED-based transmitters. Each heatmap visualizes six key physics-based features. The normalization coefficients applied to the six physics-based features are defined as [0.025, 4e-8, 0.1, 1e-9, 2e-10, 0.1], ensuring that all feature values are scaled consistently within the visualization. In the heatmap, the origin is set at the coordinate (0, 0), where the blue vertex represents resistive features, while the red vertex indicates capacitive and inductive features. The length of each vector corresponds to the normalized physics-based feature values, with longer vectors indicating higher feature magnitudes. The color distribution in the heatmap reflects the relative size of these values, providing an intuitive visual representation of the physical characteristics extracted from each LED device.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed physics-based fingerprint features in short-term device classification, three experiments were conducted using different machine learning (ML) algorithms: KNN, Bayes, and Decision Tree. A dataset of 15,000 samples, augmented at a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 30 dB, was used for training, while testing was performed on samples with SNRs ranging from 10 to 29 dB. As summarized in Table 1, KNN achieved the highest average classification accuracy at 90.88%, followed closely by the Decision Tree at 89.05%, while Bayes yielded a comparatively lower accuracy of 75.06%. These results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed fingerprint features, which consistently achieve high classification accuracy using traditional ML methods, even under challenging testing conditions with variable SNRs.Table 1

Fig. 7 shows the confusion matrix results for the proposed fingerprint-based classification using the three classifiers. The diagonal elements reflect correctly classified samples, while the off-diagonal elements indicate misclassifications between different LED transmitters. The KNN classifier (Fig. 7(a)) demonstrates robust classification performance, with most diagonal values exceeding 0.9. However, there is a clear misclassification pattern between transmitter Tx 9 and 14, where 16% of Tx 9 samples are incorrectly identified as Tx 14. This confusion may stem from the similar features shared by Tx 9 and Tx 14, as illustrated in Fig. 6. The Bayes classifier delivers moderate performance, with prominent misclassifications among Tx 1, 12, and 15, possibly due to its limited ability to capture subtle correlations between intrinsic LED features. While the decision tree classifier achieves a classification accuracy comparable to KNN, its most significant error arises from misclassifying Tx 9 as Tx 7 and 14.Fig. 7
Confusion matrix results of proposed fingerprint-based (a) KNN, (b) Bayes, and (c) decision tree classifiers.

We have further detailed the variation in classification accuracy of the proposed fingerprint features under different SNR conditions, as shown in Fig. 8. Additionally, we investigated the stability of the proposed physics-based feature classifier across partial training datasets containing 1%, 10%, 20%, and 100% of the full data. From Fig. 8, it can be observed that the classification accuracy of all three algorithms decreases as the SNR decreases. Both KNN and Bayes classifiers achieve classification accuracies exceeding 99% when the SNR is above 20 dB. Furthermore, KNN and Decision Tree consistently outperform the Bayes classifier across all SNR levels. Notably, classifier accuracy remains relatively stable regardless of the training set size. Taking KNN as an example, the algorithm achieves average classification accuracies of 90.08%, 90.85%, 90.88%, and 90.88% for 1% (150 samples), 10% (1500 samples), 20% (3000 samples), and 100% (15,000 samples) training datasets, respectively. When the dataset size is reduced to 1% of the original dataset, the average accuracy decreases by only 0.80%. This result highlights the robustness of the proposed fingerprint features, demonstrating strong performance even with significantly reduced training samples.Fig. 8
Classification accuracy versus SNR under the different sizes of the training dataset.

Fig. 9 presents the classification accuracy of various methods across different SNR levels. The proposed model, when combined with KNN, consistently outperforms all other approaches, demonstrating superior accuracy across the entire SNR range. Notably, it achieves a significant performance advantage in low-SNR conditions (e.g., below 15 dB). The CNN also exhibits strong performance in high-SNR scenarios, benefiting from its learning ability to effectively extract intricate features. However, its reliance on high-dimensional spectrogram input makes it more sensitive to noise, which explains the accuracy drop under low SNR. Meanwhile, the circuit-based features21 with KNN yield moderate results but underperform compared to the proposed approach. This is attributed to the superior representational capability of the proposed physics-based features, which more accurately capture the complete nonlinear characteristics of LEDs, including enhanced features such as parasitics and resistance of radiative recombination. Interestingly, we also observe that under low-SNR conditions, the feature model can occasionally outperform our multi-feature physics-based model. This phenomenon is likely due to the accumulation of noise across multiple extracted parameters. The LSTM model, in particular, is less effective in this task, as its sequential modeling nature is not well suited for processing frequency-domain data, leading to underperformance across most SNR levels. In contrast, the proposed fingerprint features are compact, noise-resilient, and physically meaningful to enable a more stable classification.Fig. 9
Anti-noise accuracy comparison with the state-of-the-art methods.

Table 2 presents a comparative analysis of different methods across multiple aspects, including feature types, classifier complexity, training time, and average classification accuracy, highlighting the efficiency of the proposed physics-based feature approach. While CNN and LSTM models achieve competitive classification performance, their effectiveness comes at the cost of high computational demands. These models rely on spectrogram-based features, leading to a substantial number of trainable parameters—97,115 for CNN and 9,873 for LSTM. Consequently, they require extensive training times of 111 seconds and 433 seconds, respectively, making them impractical for real-time applications or deployment in resource-constrained environments. In contrast, the proposed physics-based feature model leverages only six selected features, significantly reducing computational complexity while achieving the highest classification accuracy (90.88%). For both the proposed model and the circuit-based baseline, we adopted the same KNN classifier to ensure that differences in performance are attributable to feature design rather than classifier complexity. Unlike deep learning models, which require extensive training and parameter tuning, the proposed method employs a lightweight KNN classifier, chosen for its simplicity and suitability for small-scale, non-parametric classification tasks, eliminating the need for deep architectures and large-scale optimization. Meanwhile, the circuit-based feature approach, which utilizes only two features, further minimizes computational overhead but at the expense of lower classification accuracy (81.29%), underscoring the trade-off between model simplicity and predictive performance. The results reaffirm the advantages of physics-informed features in balancing efficiency and accuracy, offering a lightweight yet highly effective classification approach without the computational burden associated with deep learning methods.Table 2

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This paper presented a lightweight, physics-based fingerprinting model for device identification in optical wireless communication (OWC) systems. By capturing intrinsic variations in LEDs, such as packaging parasitics and carrier diffusion, and modeling them as lumped physical parameters within an equivalent circuit, the proposed approach transforms complex power spectral data into compact, interpretable features. Extensive experimental evaluations demonstrated the robustness of the method, achieving high classification accuracy across various noise conditions, even with minimal training data. Compared to conventional deep learning-based methods, the proposed approach significantly reduces computational complexity and model size, making it particularly suitable for resource-constrained environments.

The current work focuses on validating the short-term effectiveness of the fingerprinting model, providing a strong foundation for its application in practical scenarios. Future research will investigate the long-term reliability of these fingerprints under factors such as temperature variation, temporal degradation, and even channel states, aiming to enhance the model by compensating for such effects and ensuring consistent identification performance. These findings underscore the potential of leveraging physical device characteristics to improve the efficiency and scalability of device identification in modern IoT ecosystems, offering a practical framework for secure and efficient device identification in large-scale OWC deployments.
